Source: Purpose: To determine predictors of best-corrected postoperative visual acuity (VA) in patients who underwent surgical intervention for macula-off rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.
Output: The retina is the light-sensitive layer inside the eye. The central part is called the macula. If the macula comes apart from the wall of the eye, it is called macula-off retinal detachment (MORD). The goal of this study was to see what predicts vision accuracy (with glasses or contacts if needed) after surgery in patients who had surgery for MORD caused by the retina tearing.

Source: Materials and methods: Primary macula-off retinal detachments from the University of Colorado Primary Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment Database (2012-2017) were reviewed.
Output: To do the study, we searched a University of Colorado database for MORD cases between 2012 and 2017.

Source: The primary outcome measure was a postoperative VA of 20/40 or better at least 6 months after surgery.
Output: The main outcome measure was whether patients had 20/40 vision or better at least 6 months after surgery.

Source: Patient demographics, medical history, duration of central vision loss before surgery, examination findings, operative technique, and postoperative findings were analyzed as possible predictors of postoperative visual recovery to 20/40 or better.
Output: As possible factors that might predict having 20/40 vision or better after surgery, we considered patient demographics, medical history, and how long of central vision was lost before surgery. Additionally, we considered results of exams, the surgery technique used, and exams after surgery.

Source: Results: One hundred thirty-one patients met inclusion criteria.
Output: We included 131 patients in the study.

Source: Eighty-one (61.8%) patients achieved a postoperative VA of 20/40 or better 6 or more months after surgery.
Output: Eighty-one (61.8%) patients had 20/40 vision or better 6 or more months after surgery.

Source: Patients with a single retinal break were more likely than patients with more than one break to reach a postoperative VA of 20/40 or better (76.9% vs. 55.4%, p = 0.021).
Output: Patients with a single retinal break were more likely than patients with more than one break to reach 20/40 vision or better (76.9% vs. 55.4%).

Source: Patients with a better preoperative logMAR VA had better postoperative VA (p = 0.021).
Output: Patients with better vision before surgery had better vision after surgery.

Source: Duration of central vision loss prior to surgical repair was not related to final postoperative VA in this particular study.
Output: How long central vision was lost before surgery was not related to final vision accuracy in this particular study.

Source: Conclusion: Postoperative recovery of visual acuity to 20/40 or better was significantly more common in patients with a single retinal break as well as in patients with better preoperative visual acuity.
Output: In conclusion, having 20/40 vision or better after surgery was significantly more common in patients with a single retinal break as well as in patients with better vision before surgery.

Source: Duration of central vision loss prior to surgical repair was not significantly associated with postoperative VA.
Output: How long central vision was lost before surgery was not significantly associated with vision accuracy after surgery.

Source: Bivariate analysis was performed to compare the rates of positive tests after single and multidose metronidazole.
Output: We used statistical analysis to compare the rates of positive tests after single and multi-dose metronidazole.

Source: Results: Five hundred forty-two women with 565 pregnancies were diagnosed with Trichomonas infection.
Output: In this study, 542 women with 565 pregnancies were diagnosed with Trichomonas infection.

Source: The majority of subjects were prescribed either single-dose (n = 352) or multidose metronidazole (n = 74).
Output: Most of the patients were prescribed either single-dose (352 patients) or multi-dose (74 patients) metronidazole.

Source: Posttreatment Trichomonas tests were collected 21 days or longer in 326 subjects and 44% (143) were positive.
Output: Trichomonas tests were done 21 days or longer after treatment in 326 patients. Forty-four percent of these tests were positive.

Source: Rates of positive Trichomonas tests among women receiving single-dose and multidose regimens were similar (45% vs. 40%, P = 0.50).
Output: The fraction of positive Trichomonas tests among women that got single-dose and multi-dose treatments were similar (45% vs. 40%).

Source: Conclusions: Given high rates of positive Trichomonas tests and increased detection with nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs), all pregnant women should be retested with NAATs approximately 3 weeks posttreatment.
Output: There are high rates of positive Trichomonas tests. Newer nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs), which look for Trichomonas genetic material, also improve detection. Because of this, we conclude that all pregnant women should be tested again with NAATs around 3 weeks after treatment.

Source: Objective: To assess the effect on hemostasis parameters of a new combined oral contraceptive (COC).
Output: Combination birth control pills have more than one drug in the same pill. The goal of this study was to see what effect combination birth control pills have on the body’s ability to form clots to prevent bleeding. We measure this ability indirectly by looking at certain markers.

Source: Study design: In this randomized, single centre, open-label, exploratory study, healthy women received either 15 mg estetrol/3 mg drospirenone (E4/DRSP) (n = 39), 30 mcg ethinylestradiol/150 mcg levonorgestrel (EE/LNG) (n = 30), or 20 mcg ethinylestradiol/3 mg drospirenone (EE/DRSP) (n = 32) for six 28-day cycles.
Output: The study was done in a single healthcare center. Patients were healthy women. They were randomly assigned treatments but knew what they were getting. Source: Blood was collected at baseline, cycle 3, and cycle 6.
Output: Blood was collected at the start, the third cycle, and the sixth cycle.

Source: Median change from baseline was evaluated for procoagulant, anticoagulant, and fibrinolytic parameters, and for sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG).
Output: We looked for changes in blood components that promote, discourage, and dissolve clots. We also looked for changes in sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG), a marker associated with increased risk of blood clots.

Source: Results: Median change of endogenous thrombin potential (ETP) based activated protein C sensitivity resistance (APCr) at cycle 6 was +30% for E4/DRSP, +165% for EE/LNG (p-value <0.05 vs E4/DRSP), and +219% for EE/DRSP (p-value <0.05 vs E4/DRSP).
Output: We measured the tendency of blood to clot with a lab test. The average increase in clotting tendency compared to the start of the study was 30% for E4/DRSP, 165% for EE/LNG, and 219% for EE/DRSP.

Source: Changes to prothrombin fragment 1 + 2 and SHBG for E4/DRSP, EE/LNG, and EE/DRSP were +23%, +71%, and +64% (p-value <0.05 vs E4/DRSP); and +55%, +74% and +251% (p-value <0.05 vs E4/DRSP), respectively.
Output: A marker of clotting within the body increased by 23% for E4/DRSP, by 71% for EE/LNG, and by 64% for EE/DRSP. SHBG increased by 55% for E4/DRSP, 74% for EE/LNG, and 251% for EE/DRSP.

Source: At cycle 6, changes to other hemostasis parameters for E4/DRSP were similar or smaller than for EE/LNG or EE/DRSP.
Output: At cycle 6, changes to other clotting measurements for E4/DRSP were similar or smaller than for EE/LNG or EE/DRSP.

Source: Conclusions: In this study, changes in hemostasis parameters after treatment with 6 cycles of E4/DRSP were smaller or similar to those observed for EE/LNG.
Output: In conclusions, in this study, changes in clotting measurements after treatment with 6 cycles of E4/DRSP were smaller or similar to those observed for EE/LNG.

Source: Similar, but more pronounced changes were also observed versus EE/DRSP, which supports the hypothesis that the effect of COCs on hemostasis parameters is mainly mediated by the estrogenic component.
Output: We also saw similar, but stronger changes compared to EE/DRSP. This supports the idea that combination birth control pills change clotting factors mostly via estrogen.

Source: Further studies are needed to provide more insight into the venous thromboembolic risk of E4/DRSP.
Output: More studies need to be done to find out more about the risk of blood clots for E4/DRSP.

Source: Implications statement: This study reports that the effects on hemostasis parameters of a COC containing 15 mg E4/3 mg DRSP are less or similar to those for EE/LNG or EE/DRSP.
Output: Implications of this study are that the effects on clotting of a combination birth control pill with 15 mg E4 and 3 mg DRSP are less or similar to pills with EE and LNG or with EE and DRSP.

Source: It also demonstrates that the choice of estrogen modulates the effects of COCs on hemostasis parameters.
Output: The study also shows that the choice of estrogen changes the effects of combination birth control pills on clotting measurements.

Source: Purpose: This study investigated the prevalence, location, and severity of neck and shoulder pain (NSP), its disturbance of quality of life (QOL), and the factors related to NSP in Japanese postpartum women.

Source: Importance: There is considerable public and scientific debate as to whether screen use helps or hinders early child development, particularly the development of language skills.
Output: This study is importance because there’s a lot of public and scientific debate over whether screen use helps or harms early child development. The is particularly true for developing language skills.

Source: Objective: To examine via meta-analyses the associations between quantity (duration of screen time and background television), quality (educational programming and co-viewing), and onset of screen use and children's language skills.
Output: Our goal was to look at the associations between quantity, quality, and introduction of screen use and children's language skills. By quantity we mean length of screen time and background television. By quality we mean whether programming was educational and whether adults viewed with children. We looked at these associations by analyzing data grouped from other studies.

Source: Data sources: Searches were conducted in MEDLINE, Embase, and PsycINFO in March 2019.
Output: We searched several databases in March 2019.

Source: The search strategy included a publication date limit from 1960 through March 2019.
Output: We limited the search to publications dated from 1960 through March 2019.

Source: Study selection: Inclusion criteria were a measure of screen use; a measure of language skills; and statistical data that could be transformed into an effect size.
Output: We only included studies that had a measure of screen use, a measure of language skills, and data we could draw statistical conclusions from.

Source: Exclusion criteria were qualitative studies; child age older than 12 years; and language assessment preverbal.
Output: We excluded studies if they were subjective instead of making measurements. We also excluded studies on children older than 12 years and that assessed non-verbal communication before learning language.

Source: Data extraction and synthesis: The following variables were extracted: effect size, child age and sex, screen measure type, study publication year, and study design.
Output: The data we collected from the studies included: the size of differences seen, child age and sex, and how screen time was measured. The data we collected also included the year the study was published and how the study was done.

Source: Main outcomes and measures: Based on a priori study criteria, quantity of screen use included duration of screen time and background television, quality of screen use included co-viewing and exposure to educational programs, and onset of screen use was defined as the age children first began viewing screens.
Output: Based on the types of studies we chose to include, we decided that “quantity” of screen use included length of screen time and background TV. We further decided “quality” of screen use included whether adults watched alongside children and the amount of educational programs. Finally, we decided introduction to screen use was defined as the age children first began viewing screens.

Source: The child language outcome included assessments of receptive and/or expressive language.
Output: Measurements of children’s language skills included tests of understanding or using language, or both.

Source: Results: Participants totaled 18 905 from 42 studies included.
Output: In total, there were 18,905 participants from 42 studies we included.

Source: Greater quantity of screen use (hours per use) was associated with lower language skills (screen time [n = 38; r = -0.14; 95% CI, -0.18 to -0.10]; background television [n = 5; r = -0.19; 95% CI, -0.33 to -0.05]), while better-quality screen use (educational programs [n = 13; r = 0.13; 95% CI, 0.02-0.24]; co-viewing [n = 12; r = 0.16; 95% CI, 0.07-.24]) were associated with stronger child language skills.
Output: More hours of screen use was associated with lower language skills. This was true of both screen time, which was measured in 38 studies, and background TV, which was measured in 5 studies. On the other hand, better-quality screen use was associated with stronger child language skills. This was true of both educational programs (measured in 13 studies), and having an adult view with the child (measured in 12 studies).

Source: Later age at screen use onset was also associated with stronger child language skills [n = 4; r = 0.17; 95% CI, 0.07-0.27].
Output: Later age at first screen use was also associated with stronger child language skills, as measured in 4 studies.

Source: Conclusions and relevance: The findings of this meta-analysis support pediatric recommendations to limit children's duration of screen exposure, to select high-quality programming, and to co-view when possible.
Output: and relevance: In conclusion, the results of this analysis of data from existing studies support several pediatric recommendations. These recommendations include limiting children's length of screen exposure, selecting high-quality programming, and viewing with the child when possible.

Source: Background: To examine our initial experience in carotid stenting (CS) for the prevention of stroke in patients with high-grade carotid stenoses.
Output: The carotid artery supplies a lot of blood to the brain. If it becomes narrowed, it can cause strokes. Source: Results: Sixty participants were randomised into the experimental group (n = 30) or the control group (n = 30).

Source: Functional neurologic disorder (FND)/conversion disorder is a prevalent and disabling condition at the intersection of neurology and psychiatry.
Output: Functional neurologic disorder (FND) is when you’re physically fine but have problems with movement or senses. It’s also known as conversion disorder. FND is common and disabling. FND is of interest to both neurology (the study of the brain and nerves) and psychiatry (the medical study of mental disorders).

Source: Clinicians often report feeling ill-equipped treating patients with FND, perpetuated by a historically limited understanding of neurobiologic disease mechanisms.
Output: Doctors often say they are not prepared to treat patients with FND. This continues because of a historically limited understanding of how brain disorders work.

Source: In this review, we summarize the neuroimaging literature across the spectrum of sensorimotor FND, including functional imaging studies during rest, sensorimotor performance, and emotional-processing tasks as well as structural magnetic resonance imaging findings.
Output: In this review, we summarize the brain imaging research for all types of FND that involve the senses and movement functions. This research includes real-time imaging studies during rest, particular activities, and emotional-processing tasks. The research also includes MRI snapshots to look at structures.

Source: Particular attention is given to studies implicating the anterior and middle cingulate cortex and related salience network structures (insula, amygdala, and periaqueductal gray) in the neurobiology of FND.
Output: We especially look at research that suggest a role of the midcingulate cortex (MCC) and other related brain regions in the formation of FND. The MCC is thought to be important for reward-based decision-making.

Source: Neuroimaging studies identify cingulo-insular functional alterations during rest, motor performance, and emotion processing in FND populations.
Output: The MCC connects with the insula, another brain region. Brain imaging research has shown that this connection is different in people with FND during rest, physical activities, and emotion processing.

Source: The structural neuroimaging literature also implicates cingulo-insular areas in the pathophysiology of FND, though these findings require replication and clarification.
Output: Static brain imaging research also suggests the connection between the MCC and insula has a role in FND. However, these findings need to be reproduced and clarified.

Source: While more research is needed to fully elucidate the pathophysiology of FND, salience network alterations appear present in some FND populations and can be contextualized using biopsychosocial models for FND.
Output: More research is needed to completely explain how FND works. However, it seems that changes in the connections among the MCC and related brain regions appear in some people with FND. The importance of these changes can be learned by thinking about FND in terms of the impact of brain regions on mental and social functions.

Source: Background: It is critical to developing an accurate method for differentiating between malignant and benign solitary pulmonary nodules.
Output: It is very important to create an accurate way to tell if single lung nodes are cancer.

Source: This study aimed was to establish a predicting model of lung nodules malignancy in a real-world setting.
Output: This study aimed to make a model to predict if lung nodes are cancer in a real-world setting.

Source: Methods: The authors retrospectively analysed the clinical and computed tomography (CT) data of 121 patients with lung nodules, submitted to percutaneous CT-guided transthoracic biopsy, between 2014 and 2015.
Output: We looked back at medical records and CT scans of 121 patients with lung nodes. These were patients that went on to have a needle biopsy guided into the chest by CT scan. We looked at patients between 2014 and 2015.

Source: Multiple logistic regression was used to screen independent predictors for malignancy and to establish a clinical prediction model to evaluate the probability of malignancy.
Output: We used statistics to see what predicted cancer. This also let us make a model to judge the chance of cancer.

Source: Results: From a total of 121 patients, 75 (62%) were men and with a mean age of 64.7 years old.
Output: From a total of 121 patients, 75 were men. The average age was 65.

Source: Multivariate logistic regression analysis identified six independent predictors of malignancy: age, gender, smoking status, current extra-pulmonary cancer, air bronchogram and nodule size (p<0.05).
Output: The statistics found six things that each predicted cancer on their own. These included age, gender, smoking, other non-lung cancer, and node size. The last was visible airway branches on the scan, which means the surrounding air sacs are filled with fluid.

Source: Conclusions: The prediction model established in this study can be used to assess the probability of malignancy in the Portuguese population, thereby providing help for the diagnosis of lung nodules and the selection of follow-up interventions.
Output: Doctors can use the model from this study to judge the chance of cancer in the Portuguese population. This will help diagnose lung nodes and choose follow-up treatments.

Source: Purpose: As obesity rates continue to climb, the notion that overconsumption reflects an underlying 'food addiction' (FA) has become increasingly influential.
Output: As obesity rates keep getting higher, the idea that eating too much reflects 'food addiction’ has shaped the conversation more.

Source: An increasingly popular theory is that sugar acts as an addictive agent, eliciting neurobiological changes similar to those seen in drug addiction.
Output: A theory getting more popular is that sugar acts as an addictive substance. In this case, it causes brain changes similar to those seen in drug addiction.

Source: In this paper, we review the evidence in support of sugar addiction.
Output: In this paper, we review the evidence that supports sugar addiction.

Source: Methods: We reviewed the literature on food and sugar addiction and considered the evidence suggesting the addictiveness of highly processed foods, particularly those with high sugar content.
Output: We reviewed the research on food and sugar addiction. We considered the evidence suggesting that highly processed foods are addictive. This especially concerns foods with a lot of sugar.

Source: We then examined the addictive potential of sugar by contrasting evidence from the animal and human neuroscience literature on drug and sugar addiction.
Output: We then looked at the addictive power of sugar. We did this by comparing evidence from the animal and human brain science literature on drug and sugar addiction.

Source: Results: We find little evidence to support sugar addiction in humans, and findings from the animal literature suggest that addiction-like behaviours, such as bingeing, occur only in the context of intermittent access to sugar.
Output: We didn’t find much evidence of sugar addiction in humans. Results from the animal studies suggests that addiction-like behaviors, like bingeing, only happen for on-and-off access to sugar.

Source: These behaviours likely arise from intermittent access to sweet tasting or highly palatable foods, not the neurochemical effects of sugar.
Output: These behaviors likely come from occasional access to sweet or very tasty foods. That is, it’s not the chemical effects of sugar on the brain.

Source: Conclusion: Given the lack of evidence supporting it, we argue against a premature incorporation of sugar addiction into the scientific literature and public policy recommendations.
Output: We argue against adding sugar addiction to the scientific literature and public policy recommendations. This would be premature. There is just not enough evidence supporting it.

Source: When used appropriately, immunization can effectively prevent many infections and diseases.
Output: Vaccines can effectively prevent many infections and diseases when used the right way.

Source: Some vaccines, such as that for polio, are believed to produce lifelong immunity.
Output: We think some vaccines make you immune for life. The polio vaccine is one example.

Source: Others, such as those for tetanus and diphtheria, may require that a booster injection be given upon exposure to assure full immunity.
Output: Others vaccines may need a booster to ensure full immunity after exposure. Examples are vaccines for tetanus and diphtheria.

Source: Still others, such as that for influenza, confer immunity for only a limited time.
Output: Still others only make you immune for some time. An example is the flu shot.

Source: Inoculation is not without risk, particularly in immunosuppressed, allergic, febrile, or pregnant patients.
Output: Vaccines do have risks. This is especially true for people that are allergic, feverish, pregnant, or have weakened immune systems.

Source: However, in otherwise healthy patients, serious sequelae are so rare that they are far overshadowed by the enormous benefits of immunization.
Output: However, serious side effects are rare in people that are healthy otherwise. So rare, in fact, that the huge benefits of vaccines far outweigh them.

Source: Multiple myeloma is an incurable haematological cancer.
Output: Multiple myeloma (MM) is a blood cancer. There is no cure.

Source: The increase in targeted therapies has improved the number of myeloma patients achieving a complete response and improved progression-free survival following therapy.
Output: More treatments specifically for MM have meant more patients with no trace of cancer left. Patients also have more time without the cancer getting worse.

Source: However, a low level of disease or minimal residual disease (MRD) still persists which contributes to the inevitable relapse in myeloma patients.
Output: Still, a small amount of cancer sticks around. This means sooner or later, MM comes back.

Source: MRD has been attributed to the presence of dormant myeloma cells and their subsequent reactivation, which is controlled by the microenvironment and specialised niches within the bone marrow.
Output: Traces of cancer might come from dormant cancer cells that become active again. This is controlled by certain microscopic parts of the bone marrow they live in.

Source: This contributes to the evasion of the immune system and chemotherapy, eventually leading to relapse.
Output: This helps the cancer escape the immune system and chemo. Eventually this leads to relapse.

Source: The growth of myeloma tumours are heavily dependent on environmental stimuli from the bone marrow microenvironment, and this plays a key role in myeloma progression.
Output: The growth of MM tumors depends on signals from tiny things in the surrounding bone marrow. This plays a key role in MM getting worse.

Source: The bone microenvironment also plays a critical role in myeloma bone disease and the development of skeletal-related events.
Output: The microscopic parts of bone also play a critical role in MM bone disease and in bone pain and breaks.

Source: This review focuses on the bone marrow microenvironment in relation to myeloma pathogenesis and cancer dormancy.
Output: This review focuses on the bone marrow at the microscopic level. It discusses this as it pertains to MM starting and coming back.

Source: Moreover, it reviews the current therapies targeting the bone microenvironment to treat myeloma and myeloma bone disease.
Output: What’s more, it surveys the current treatments that target bone at the microscopic level. This is to treat MM and related bone problems.

Source: Lastly, it identifies novel therapeutic targets for myeloma treatment and the associated bone disease.
Output: Finally, the review lists new ideas for how to make drugs to treat MM and related bone problems.

Source: Breastfed infants have a growth pattern that is different from formula-fed infants, which is regarded as the optimal growth pattern.
Output: The growth pattern of breastfed infants is different from formula-fed infants. This is thought of as the best growth pattern.

Source: Breastfed infants increase more in weight, length, and BMI during the first 2-3 months of life and then have a slower growth velocity up to 12 months.
Output: Breastfed infants grow more in weight, length, and BMI in the first 2 to 3 months. Then they grow more slowly up to 12 months.

Source: They also have a higher accumulation of fat during early infancy.
Output: They build up more fat during early infancy.

Source: Breastfed infants have lower levels of circulating IGF-I and insulin, which could be part of the explanation of their growth pattern.
Output: Breastfed infants have lower levels of a growth hormone and insulin in their blood. This could partly explaion their growth pattern.

Source: Many studies and meta-analyses have examined the association between breastfeeding and later obesity.
Output: Many trials and pooled data studies have looked at the link between breastfeeding and later obesity.

Source: Most find a moderate reduction in the risk of later obesity, but it has been argued that this could be biased due to residual confounding and reverse causation.
Output: Most find somewhat less risk of later obesity. Yet, some argue that this might not be cause-and-effect because of other factors.

Source: From studies in low- and middle-income countries randomizing women to breastfeeding promotion, there was only little effect on early growth.
Output: Studies in low- and middle-income countries women have promoted breastfeeding to only some women, randomly. There was only a little change in early growth.

Source: Recent studies have found associations between breast milk composition (total fat, protein, human milk oligosaccharides, adiponectin, leptin, and insulin) and growth.
Output: Recent studies have found links between breast milk makeup and growth. This includes levels of total fat, protein, complex sugars, and hormones.

Source: However, the studies are few, and the results are inconsistent.
Output: Still, there aren’t many studies, and the results are inconsistent.

Source: More studies, including studies of maternal factors influencing breast milk composition, are needed to better understand how breastfeeding influences current and later growth and thereby short- and long-term health.
Output: We need more studies to better understand how breastfeeding affects current and later growth. This in turn affects short- and long-term health. Studies should look at, for example, how the mother’s health and lifestyle affects the makeup of breastmilk.

Source: Constipation is a disorder of gastrointestinal motility characterized by difficult or decreased bowel movements, and is a common condition in Western countries.
Output: Constipation is a digestion problem. It involves bowel movements that are hard and happen less. Constipation is a common problem in Western countries.

Source: Laxatives are the most common strategy for managing constipation.
Output: Laxatives are the most common treatment for constipation.

Source: However, long-term use of some laxatives may be associated with harmful side-effects including increased constipation and fecal impaction.
Output: But, taking some laxatives long-term may come with harmful side-effects. These include more constipation and bowel blockages.

Source: Abdominal massage, once an accepted method of treating constipation, is no longer standard of care, but may be a desirable therapy for this condition because it is inexpensive, non-invasive, free of harmful side-effects, and can be performed by patients themselves.
Output: Massaging the belly used to be an accepted constipation remedy. This is not considered the standard treatment anymore. Yet, it may be a good way to treat constipation because it’s cheap and doesn’t involve surgery. It also has no harmful side-effects and patients can do it themselves.

Source: However, until recently, evidence for its effectiveness was not strong enough to make a recommendation for its use in constipated patients.
Output: However, until recently, evidence that it worked wasn’t strong enough to recommend it to constipated patients.

Source: In 1999, Ernst reviewed all available controlled clinical trials, and found that there was no sound evidence for the effectiveness of abdominal massage in the treatment of chronic constipation.
Output: In 1999, Ernst reviewed all clinical trials at the time. Ernst found that there was no sound evidence that belly massage worked to treat long-term constipation.

Source: This article reviews scientific evidence from 1999 to the present, regarding abdominal massage as an intervention for chronic constipation.
Output: This article will look at scientific evidence from 1999 to today. It will concern belly massage to treat for long-term constipation.

Source: Since that time, studies have demonstrated that abdominal massage can stimulate peristalsis, decrease colonic transit time, increase the frequency of bowel movements in constipated patients, and decrease the feelings of discomfort and pain that accompany it.
Output: Since then, studies have shown that belly massage can jumpstart digestion in constipated patients. It can also make stool move through the colon faster and make bowel movements happen more often. Finally, the studies show that belly massage can lessen the discomfort and pain that come with constipation.

Source: There is also good evidence that massage can stimulate peristalsis in patients with post-surgical ileus.
Output: There is also good evidence that massage can jumpstart digestion in patients whose bowels aren’t working because they just had surgery.

Source: Individual case reports show that massage has been effective for patients with constipation due to a variety of diagnosed physiologic abnormalities, as well as in patients with long-term functional constipation.
Output: Individual cases show that massage works for patients with constipation from several known causes. They also show it works in patients with long-term constipation arising on its own.
